So if it sounds like a collection of old outtakes at times, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the point. And if it has more in common with the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s post-Syd Barrett, pre-superstardom records than the mid-Ã¢â‚¬â„¢70s epics that turned on millions of headphones-wielding fans, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sorta the point, too.
The Endless River sounds like it was made by a band in transition. And in a way, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pretty much what Pink Floyd are these days, with only singer-guitarist David Gilmour and drummer Nick Mason left. Wright plays on these tracks, but heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s almost an ethereal spirit here, drifting above, below and alongside the songs with ghostly detachment. He gives Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Endless RiverÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ its familiar qualities, but he also gives it some purpose and some of its aimlessness.

As such, donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t go into the album expecting Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Dark Side of the Moon,Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ Ã¢â‚¬ËœWish You Were HereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ or even Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Division Bell.Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Endless RiverÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is subtler, and less inviting, than that. This is not an album of songs so much as it is a collection of ambient music pieces, sculpted together from leftover fragments of a 20-year-old album that, letÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s face it, is no classic.

But tracks like the opening Ã¢â‚¬ËœThings Left Unsaid,Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ Ã¢â‚¬ËœItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s What We DoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ (whose synth and rhythm passages echo Ã¢â‚¬ËœWelcome to the MachineÃ¢â‚¬â„¢) and Ã¢â‚¬ËœAllons-Y (2),Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ which features a signature searing Gilmour guitar solo, remind fans that, before they became one of the planetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s biggest rock bands, Pink Floyd were scoring long, complex instrumental pieces for people to trip out to.

Unfortunately, it doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t always come together seamlessly. The sweeping Ã¢â‚¬ËœAnisina,Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ a highlight, gives way to Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Lost Art of Conversation,Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ a short, snoozy piano-based track that leads a string of similar, less-than-two-minute songs that were most likely unfinished studio fragments in their original forms. And the plodding Ã¢â‚¬ËœTalkinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ HawkinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢,Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ which includes a sampled 1994 commercial with physicist Stephen Hawking (and is a sorta sequel to Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Division BellÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½s Ã¢â‚¬ËœKeep TalkingÃ¢â‚¬â„¢), is more novelty than a fully formed number.

So when GilmourÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s voice cuts through the clutter on  Ã¢â‚¬â„¢Louder Than Words,Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ the closing track and the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s only song with a lead vocal, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s like a memory from the past, reminding us that Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Endless RiverÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is a Pink Floyd album.
